Situation1: This is the last weekend before the partner relocates abroad for months.
Expectation2: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation2: The call volume is light, and supervisors allow flexible timing for breaks.
Story:
I glance at the clock on my phone, my thumb hovering over the “log out” button on my telemarketing app. It’s Saturday afternoon, and the office is quiet—most of my coworkers have already taken their breaks, and the call volume is unusually low. My supervisor said we could be flexible today, but I know I’m still expected to stick to my scheduled hours. 

But then I look over at my boyfriend, sprawled on the couch, scrolling through photos of apartments in Berlin. This is our last weekend together before he leaves for months, and he’s been hinting all morning that he wants to go out, maybe take a walk or grab coffee at our favorite spot. I promised him we’d spend real time together, not just sit in the same room while I work. 

My heart twists as I weigh the expectations—be the reliable employee, or the loving girlfriend who makes these last hours count. I can feel his eyes on me, waiting, hoping. My supervisor’s words echo in my mind, but so do his. I stare at my phone, torn, not sure which role I’m supposed to choose.
